channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Russia Welcomes Talks, Biden Warns Invasion Is Still Possible
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said he was pulling some Russian troops back from areas close to Ukraine, hinting at cooling the crisis, but U.S. officials say it is too soon to gauge his intentions.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: A Ukrainian Army front line position on Tuesday near Syze, in the Luhansk Oblast of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: On Ukraine, U.S. and Russia Wage Signaling War to Avert Actual War
item.description: Each side is trying to convince the other that the price of conflict is too high. It is a complex game played with deliberate ambiguity, raising the risk of lethal miscalculation.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: American soldiers deploying to Eastern Europe on Monday at Fort Bragg, N.C.

item.title: Putin's Motives Pose a Challenge for U.S. Intelligence Agencies
item.description: Knowing the intentions of any autocratic leader is difficult, but President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who began his career as a K.G.B. officer, poses a particular challenge.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin’s calculus is likely shifting as he weighs the risks of an invasion against what he believes he could gain through negotiations, according to a U.S. official.

item.title: Sandy Hook Families Reach Settlement With Gunmaker Remington
item.description: Victims’ families had sued Remington, the maker of the AR-15-style weapon used in the attack at an elementary school in Newtown, Conn.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Karen Zraick and Troy Closson
item.media:description: Mary D’Avino held a photo of her daughter, Rachel D’Avino, one of the victims of the Sandy Hook school massacre, during a news conference on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Men’s Hockey Is Eliminated in Loss to Slovakia
item.description: The American team is out of the Olympics after a quarterfinal game that ended in a penalty shootout. Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Alex Hall and Nick Goepper Take Gold and Silver in Men’s Slopestyle Skiing
item.description: Alex Hall and Nick Goepper crowd the podium in the freeski event. Teammate Colby Stevenson was hoping to make a sweep with bronze, but came in seventh.
item.dc:creator: John Branch
item.media:description: The American skiers Alex Hall, left, and Nick Goepper took gold and silver in slopestyle skiing on Wednesday.

item.title: Valieva's Competitors May Be Denied the Ultimate Olympic Thrill
item.description: Because of the doping scandal involving Kamila Valieva of Russia, her top competitors may be denied the joy of receiving a medal on the Olympic podium during the Games.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Streeter
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Kamila Valieva of Russia competing in the women’s singles short program on Tuesday at the Beijing Olympics.

item.title: Who Is the Real China? Eileen Gu or the Chained Woman?
item.description: The women’s starkly different circumstances — celebrated vs. silenced — reflect that to the Chinese state everyone is a tool that serves a purpose until it does not.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Jeff Zucker’s Downfall at CNN: Ethical Lapses and Falling Ratings
item.description: The network’s top-rated host and its president were forced out following ethical lapses, an office romance and a letter from a lawyer for “Jane Doe.”
item.dc:creator: Emily Steel, Jodi Kantor, Michael M. Grynbaum, James B. Stewart and John Koblin
item.media:description: Jeff Zucker’s abrupt departure has thrown the future of CNN into chaos.

item.title: Jury Rejects Sarah Palin’s Libel Case Against The Times
item.description: The verdict came a day after the judge said that he planned to dismiss the case in which Ms. Palin accuses the paper of defamation. Get business updates.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sarah Palin’s Libel Claim Against The Times Is Rejected by a Jury
item.description: The verdict came a day after the judge said he planned to dismiss the case, ruling that Ms. Palin’s legal team had failed to prove that the newspaper defamed her.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sarah Palin arriving in court on Tuesday. She is expected to appeal the jury’s finding.

item.title: Behind the Fractious Collaboration Steering the Canada Protests
item.description: The organizers include former law enforcement officers, military veterans and conservative organizers who are steering unrest that has sent shock waves throughout Canada.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir and Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:description: Vehicles block a road outside the Parliament in Ottawa on Tuesday.

item.title: Prince Andrew Settles Sexual Abuse Lawsuit With Virginia Giuffre
item.description: Financial terms of the settlement, which was announced in a federal court filing in Manhattan on Tuesday, were not revealed.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: Prince Andrew did not admit guilt in the settlement, which came just weeks before he was scheduled to sit for a deposition in the case.

item.title: Prince Andrew’s Deal With Virginia Giuffre Leaves Many Questions
item.description: One question is who will pay for the settlement with the woman who accused him of raping her as a teen. But wider questions about his finances and behavior also dog the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Prince Andrew last year.

item.title: California Returns as Climate Leader, With Help From the White House
item.description: The Biden administration is restoring the state’s power to set its own limits on tailpipe pollution and is largely adopting the state’s rules regarding heavy trucks.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Patrick T. Fallon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The new rules for heavy duty vehicles, ranging from tractor-trailers to buses, would mark the first time tailpipe standards have been tightened for the biggest polluters on the road since 2001.

item.title: Coastal Sea Levels in U.S. to Rise a Foot by 2050, Study Confirms
item.description: More precise measurements indicate that the increase will happen “no matter what we do about emissions.”
item.dc:creator: Henry Fountain
item.media:description: A “sunny day” flood in Mill Valley, Calif., last month. Such events will become more damaging in the future, scientists predict.

item.title: P.J. O’Rourke, Conservative Political Satirist, Dies at 74
item.description: In articles, in best sellers and as a talk show regular he was a voice from the right skewering whatever in government or culture he thought needed it.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The author P.J. O’Rourke at his home in New Hampshire in 2009. He was widely admired for his willingness to mock just about anyone who deserved it, including himself.

item.title: Coachella Festival to Return Without Mask or Vaccine Requirements
item.description: Organizers said they could not guarantee that those attending the three-day music festival would not be exposed to Covid. Catch up on pandemic news.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: A 2,700-Year-Old Figurine Revives a Weighty Mystery
item.description: A bronze statuette recovered from a river in Germany may have been part of an early Scandinavian weight system, some archaeologists believe.
item.dc:creator: Franz Lidz

item.title: ‘Heiresses’ Adds Up the Melancholy and Danger of Inherited Wealth
item.description: Ranging from the 17th century to the 21st, Laura Thompson’s book examines the lives of ostensibly fortunate daughters.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.category: Heiresses: The Lives of the Million Dollar Babies (Book)

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Is Sleepy Joe Biden Making Vladimir Putin Blink?
item.description: Biden has given Putin reason to think through his plans further.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: War Between Ukraine and Russia Would Be a Tragedy
item.description: Conflict between the two countries would travesty centuries of commingling.
item.dc:creator: Anastasia Edel
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; Photographs courtesy of the author

item.title: Ukraine and a Post-Pax Americana World
item.description: We’ll miss it when it’s gone.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: Yes, Some Musicals Are Unwoke. That’s Not a Writ to Rewrite Them.
item.description: When Encores! aren’t encores.
item.dc:creator: John McWhorter
item.category: Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)

item.title: Trump's Trade War With China Was a Failure
item.description: Oh, what a lousy trade war.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: The Case for Eating Insects
item.description: Climate-conscious cooking means getting creative.
item.dc:creator: Tala Schlossberg, Kirk Semple and Jonah M. Kessel

item.title: ‘This is About the Future of Freedom’: What Does America Owe Ukrainians?
item.description: A debate on how the United States should be thinking about its responsibility in the Russia-Ukraine crisis.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Argument’
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Losing My Eyesight Helped Me See More Clearly
item.description: The people around me came into sharper focus, by which I mean their fears, struggles and triumphs.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: Why We Are Not Facing the Prospect of a Second Civil War
item.description: We have better things to fret over.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Joshua Rashaad McFadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Georgia State Capitol, demonstrating against the inauguration of President Biden on Jan. 20, 2021.

item.title: Other Places Should Do What Alaska Did to Its Elections
item.description: Reforms on how we vote offer hope in mitigating the forces of extremism in our politics.
item.dc:creator: Richard H. Pildes

item.title: Texas Must Update Its Power Grid
item.description: A year ago, 10 million Texans lost power in a winter storm. The state has resisted a simple fix.
item.dc:creator: Michael E. Webber
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Austin, Texas, this time last year.

item.title: What if We Respected Toddlers as Whole People?
item.description: Janet Lansbury on an unusual parenting theory that has the potential to improve all your relationships.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: The Conservative Case for Reforming the Electoral Count Act
item.description: Both parties must set aside their partisan interests and reform the Electoral Count Act.
item.dc:creator: J. Michael Luttig
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: These Policies Were Supposed to Help Black People. They’re Backfiring.
item.description: By aiming for racial equity in criminal justice, reformers have neglected the foundational purpose of law and order.
item.dc:creator: Jim Quinn and Hannah E. Meyers

item.title: We Weren’t Wrong to Love ‘The Cosby Show’
item.description: But we have to leave it behind for the same reasons we were drawn to it.
item.dc:creator: Tressie McMillan Cottom
item.category: We Need to Talk About Cosby (TV Program)

item.title: How We Are Failing Mentally Ill People
item.description: Readers describe a mental health system that one calls “inhumane, disgraceful.” Also: Columnists too downbeat on President Biden.
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times

item.title: Anna Sorokin on ‘Inventing Anna’ and Life After Rikers
item.description: In an interview ahead of the Netflix show’s release, Ms. Sorokin spoke about how her life has changed since the end of her Anna Delvey days.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Sorokin in 2019, during her trial in Manhattan. She has spent the last year in ICE detention.

item.title: Pastor Resigns After Incorrectly Performing Thousands of Baptisms
item.description: The pastor of a Catholic church in Phoenix changed one word in administering the sacrament, rendering baptisms performed there invalid, the church said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Godong/Universal Images Group via Getty Images
item.media:description: The Vatican instructs priests to say, “I baptize you in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,” but a priest incorrectly substituted “we” for “I,” the church said.

item.title: An Undiscovered Coronavirus? The Mystery of the ‘Russian Flu’
item.description: Scientists are grasping for any example that could help anticipate the future of Covid, even a mysterious respiratory pandemic that spread in the late 19th century.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Abortion Opponents Hear a ‘Heartbeat.’ Most Experts Hear Something Else.
item.description: Embedded in abortion laws in Texas are disputed assertions about embryonic development and the procedure’s risks. Chief among them: whether the early embryo has a heart.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A Texas woman received a sonogram at an abortion clinic in Oklahoma City. Some women are now leaving Texas for abortions since it enacted a “heartbeat” bill restricting the procedure last year.

item.title: Navy Nuclear Engineer Pleads Guilty in Submarine Espionage Case
item.description: Jonathan Toebbe, who was arrested in October along with his wife, is set to face 12 years or more in prison under a plea deal with federal prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Under the plea agreement, entered in federal court in Martinsburg, W.Va., Mr. Toebbe pleaded guilty to a single charge of conspiracy to communicate restricted data.

item.title: Zoology and Org Charts
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: How the Sacklers Got Away With It
item.description: Patrick Radden Keefe discusses how the family that helped create an overdose crisis that’s killed hundreds of thousands of Americans has escaped accountability.
item.dc:creator: ‘Sway’
item.category: Empire of Pain: The Secret History of the Sackler Dynasty (Book)

item.title: This YouTube Star Is Also a Retail Empire
item.description: Linus Sebastian started out making wacky videos. Now he employs fashion designers and logistics experts.
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: First Love Mixtape
item.description: What is the song you were obsessed with as a teenager? Listen to our season premiere — and share your song.
item.dc:creator: Anna Martin, Daniel Jones, Miya Lee, Julia Botero, Hans Buetow, Elisheba Ittoop and Dan Powell

item.title: San Francisco Voters Recall 3 Board of Education Members
item.description: The recall, which galvanized Asian Americans, was a victory for parents angered by the district’s priorities during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Gabrielle Lurie/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gabriela López, the president of the San Francisco school board, was one of three members targeted in the recall.

item.title: Top European Court Rules E.U. Can Freeze Aid to Poland and Hungary
item.description: In a landmark decision, the European Court of Justice approved the bloc’s decision to cut billions in aid on the grounds that members are eroding rule-of-law checks and balances.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Monika Pronczuk and Benjamin Novak
item.media:description: Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary during an annual state of the nation speech in Budapest last week.

item.title: Jan. 6 Inquiry Subpoenas 6 Tied to False Pro-Trump Elector Effort
item.description: The committee is digging deeper into a plan by former President Donald J. Trump’s allies to reverse his election loss in key states by sending fake slates of electors who would say he won.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark W. Finchem, an Arizona state legislator, was among those subpoenaed.

item.title: A Woman Is Cured of H.I.V. Using a Novel Treatment
item.description: She’s the third person ever to be cured. Researchers announced that the new approach holds the potential for curing more people of racially diverse backgrounds.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of H.I.V. particles, in yellow, infecting a host cell. The patient received cord blood from a donor with the mutation that blocks H.I.V.’s entry into cells.

item.title: Democrats Weigh Gas Tax Holiday and Deficit Cuts as Inflation Mounts
item.description: Democrats are looking to revamp their legislative agenda to focus on relief for rising prices before November’s midterm elections while trying to salvage their social policy bill.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We’re going to focus like a laser on reducing costs — the new proposals and new ideas keep coming,” said Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the majority leader.

item.title: At Least 10 Dead After Spanish Fishing Vessel Sinks in Atlantic
item.description: Many are missing from a fishing boat carrying 24 people that sank about 280 miles off the coast of Newfoundland, Canada, on Tuesday, Spanish officials said.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer and Raphael Minder
item.media:description: The Villa de Pitanxo, a 164-foot long vessel, at the Port of Marín, in Galicia, Spain in 2019.

item.title: Kathleen Rice Announces Her Retirement From Congress
item.description: The decision by Representative Kathleen Rice of New York makes the number of Democrats leaving Congress the largest since 1992, as midterm elections loom.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: Representative Kathleen Rice announced on Tuesday that she would not seek re-election, and that she was moving on to the “next chapter” of her life.

item.title: Sonny Perdue Is Sole Finalist to Lead Georgia’s Public Universities
item.description: The Board of Regents announced that the former Republican governor is its choice to become chancellor. His selection has angered professors concerned about academic freedom.
item.dc:creator: Giulia Heyward
item.category: Southern Association of Colleges and Schools
item.media:description: Sonny Perdue served two terms as governor of Georgia before being named Agriculture Secretary in the Trump administration.

item.title: Alec Baldwin and ‘Rust’ Producers Sued for Halyna Hutchins’s Death
item.description: The suit charges that Baldwin “recklessly shot and killed Halyna Hutchins on the set” and that the production’s “aggressive cost-cutting” had endangered the crew.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs and Graham Bowley
item.media:description: Halyna Hutchins, the cinematographer who was shot and killed last year on the set of “Rust,” in an undated photo.

item.title: Prosecutors Focus on Arbery Killers’ Failure to Help as He Lay Dying
item.description: The men were previously convicted of murder. The government is now trying to build a case that racism fueled their actions.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Stephen B. Morton
item.media:description: Gregory McMichael, center, and his son, Travis McMichael, entering the courtroom during their state murder trial in November.

item.title: Victim’s Rape Kit Helped Identify Her as a Suspect in Another Case, D.A. Says
item.description: Chesa Boudin, the district attorney in San Francisco, said victims are “being treated like criminals,” and he wants legislators to ban the practice.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Gabrielle Lurie/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “We should encourage survivors to come forward — not collect evidence to use against them in the future,” District Attorney Chesa Boudin of San Francisco said.

item.title: U.S. Temporarily Bans Avocados From Mexico, Citing Threat
item.description: The move is a blow to the Mexican state of Michoacán, which exports roughly $3 billion worth of the fruit annually.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Celia Talbot Tobin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mexico supplies about 80 percent of the avocados eaten in the United States.

item.title: What We Know About Long Covid and Exercise
item.description: And experts have some theories as to why.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer

item.title: Shifting the Focus of Breast Cancer to Prevention
item.description: If protective measures were widely adopted, they could significantly reduce women’s chances of ever getting breast cancer.
item.dc:creator: Jane E. Brody

item.title: Treating Chronic Pain Takes a Team. I Had to Build My Own.
item.description: The U.S. health care system can be difficult for anyone to navigate — even more so if you’re a Black woman. So one writer spent a decade building her own care.
item.dc:creator: Kari Cobham
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Justin J Wee for The New York Times. Prop stylist: Caroline Dorn.

item.title: Respecting Children’s Pain
item.description: A new study challenges those who care for children to end what researchers say is the common undertreatment of pain in children, starting at birth.
item.dc:creator: Perri Klass, M.D.

item.title: The Financial Toxicity of Illness
item.description: While medicine transforms cancer into a chronic disease with which patients can live for an extended period of time, financial toxicity threatens to turn chronic, too.
item.dc:creator: Susan Gubar

item.title: 24 Brilliant Baking Recipes to Change Your Kitchen Game
item.description: These delectable treats are full of light-bulb moments that educate as much as they impress.
item.dc:creator: Krysten Chambrot
item.media:credit: Christopher Simpson for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Simon Andrews.

item.title: A Timeline of Kanye West's Relationships
item.description: The artist now known as Ye has vacillated between begging Kim Kardashian to take him back and publicly criticizing her — all while briefly dating someone new.
item.dc:creator: Gina Cherelus
item.media:description: Julia Fox and Kanye West in Paris for couture week.

item.title: Looking Back on a Colonial Struggle, a Museum Stirs New Disputes
item.description: At the Netherlands’ national museum, describing the events in which Indonesia threw off Dutch colonial rule was never going to be easy.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal

item.title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Never Good Enough, Never Skinny Enough’
item.description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.

item.title: Why Olga Tokarczuk Likes to Read T.S. Eliot in Translation
item.description: “It’s fascinating to read poetry in its original form, but it’s just as fascinating to read it in a variety of translations. Suddenly the same text takes on new dimensions, as if it were growing in new directions.”
